title: What will be the end-of-day closing value of the Nikkei 225 Index on 29 December 2017?
preds: Going all in on over 22,000 because I don't think the market is going to crash in the next few days.

Taking a look at the downside, I'm averaging 60-point drops per day for next 13 trading days - 780 points still keeps it in last bin. This assumes it continues to rebound after bigger, say 100-point, drops
Want to stay further ahead of consensus
Time decay increases the chance of a close above 22k
22.908 and breaking out again, looks to have consolidated above 22,000
Shifting much higher because the Nikkei keeps going up.
22,564  Bit worried about profit taking at year end
The launch of the missiles by North Korea did not affect the Nikkei of Japan (210 km from Japan), as in previous action of North Korea

With only a little more than a month, left on the clock, the VIX very low and global GDP reasonably strong it seems like a long shot for this market to end the year below 22,000. Not impossible, but a long shot. It seems most are treating it as a 50/50 bet the market will lose nearly 3% in a month, not sure I understand that. Possibly, I am missing something.
maybe Japan's pension fund is still buying or somebody else must be picking up the slack...?

NKY:IND
22,427.00
https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/NKY:IND Run for the exits. Raahul bought gold a year ago. This crash was 100% predictable. And every stockmarket new high signals the worst fall ever seen. The Great Depression will be recognised as a little misstep. It is nothing at all compared to what is coming.

Hasn’t been below 20,000 since September. Has been above 22,000 for two weeks.
Recent increases have been attributed in some part to the Yen’s relative weakness against the U.S. Dollar. An expected increase in interest rates from the Fed in December would exacerbate this.

22,937
so long, before the launch missle in North Korea, training explosion or statement of their leader
Nikkei at an all time high and still going strong, riding the worldwide bullish trend.
the rally mode is on:  the sky is the limit.
I am of the viewpoint that there will be a global crash in stock markets before 29 December. Yet unfortunately I don't yet have a means of being precise on the date.
This market continues to move higher. I am using 9.5% vol and annual expected return of 2%.
Shifting higher due to the recent record high.

Simply using 9.5% vol (more or less consistent with the Vix) and annual expected return of about 3%, which seems reasonable to me given Japan's inflation is somewhere around 0.5% meaning the real expected return on Japanese equities is around 2.5%.
I just don’t see much market movement either way in the next few months. I say it closes at 21,500ish

Japanese stocks are forecast to scale a 21-year peak by year-end, boosted by a weaker yen and market expectations Prime Minister Shinzo Abe will prevail in a snap election he called for Oct. 22 in a boost for his broad political and economic agenda. Respondents in the latest Reuters poll were mostly optimistic too about further rises into 2018, as the world’s third-biggest economy continues to hum on higher corporate profits and a buoyant global outlook. The Nikkei share average .N225 is expected to trade at 21,000 at year-end, up 2 percent from Tuesday's close of 20,614.07, and 10 percent higher for 2017, according to the median forecast from 28 analysts and fund managers polled by Reuters in the past week. 
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-japan-stocks-poll/japan-stocks-to-hit-21-year-high-in-2017-on-weak-yen-election-reuters-poll-idUSKBN1CA07I?il=0

https://www.google.ie/search?q=nikkei&oq=nikkei&aqs=chrome..69i57j69i60.2073j0j4&sourceid=chrome&ie=UTF-8
Currently 20300 and rising. It looks like the markets don't think Kim will bomb Japan in the short term! I am going to go up significantly as i think the current breakout with all the negatives about Korea and US shows good strength in the market.

Abe has strong support for October election. IMF supported economic stimulus likely to continue.
https://asia.nikkei.com/Politics-Economy/Policy-Politics/Japan-s-ruling-party-far-ahead-of-opposition-as-election-nears

IMF agrees with continued stimulus:
http://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-imf-japan/imf-says-boj-should-maintain-stimulus-allow-for-delay-in-exit-idUKKCN1BX0FV?il=0 BoJ vote 8-1 to maintain negative rate:
https://finance.yahoo.com/news/boj-keeps-monetary-spigot-open-051642049.html
Weaker yen + strong possibility of a 3rd Abe term.

up days	           Sept 2016 -Sept 2017:     127, July/Aug/Sept:       23,         Apr/July:          32
down days	                          117	                          29	                   30 seems to be in a downward trend but sooo close to topping 20K --- if it averaged 3 points for the next 80 trading days (and it regularly swings much more than that)  it would be 20K + Comment: reply boxes would benefit from better word processing (i.e tables, images, charts, even tabbing and alignment for better probability explanations and for  data enrichment of comments/discussions and replies
My RORO model suggests that risk assets will continue to outperform, and my cross-sectional  model suggests that Japan is likely to outperform other equity markets.
Currently 19357, chart seems to have turned down - north Korea effect???
Using 11% vol, in line with the VIX (may or may not be a good assumption) and 2% expected return (may or may not be a good assumption).
Shifting a little higher because the index has been hovering below 20,000 for months.
Really strong buying pressure at 19,000.  Over the next 5 months I expect that to push the price above 20,000

Increasing > 20K bucket slightly after the threshold has been breached, however a possible global central bank pullback in the autumn could exert a downward pressure at year-end. The BOJ and ECB have so far been coy about a possible exit from ultra-loose monetary policy, and it's possible the tapering will be pushed to 2018. In the meantime, will monitor how high the index can climb before that.
Looks slightly bullish but is at minor resistance point on weekly chart. No changes for now.
Using 10% volatility and 2% rexpected return. miscalculated earlier.

Current price $19908.56. Raising 3rd category 5% and lowering 5th by 5%. Stock markets still seem euphoric and able to dismiss negative news. N.Korea still the biggest threat to current bullish trend. Chinese militarization of South China Sea could also be an issue.
Using 10% volatility and expected 2% one year return.
Shifting my average a bit toward 20,000. The index has been moving faster than I thought.

Currently $20,177.28. Lowered 1st category to 0, lowered 2nd to 10%, raised 3rd to 35%, raised 4th to 45%. Currently very bullish on technical basis only, broke thru resistance of 19994 next resistance 20, 950.
Mild drawdown because of geopolitical tension
Using 15% volatility and 0% rexpected return. The index is already up 5% YTD, that seems like a lot given the near zero inflation in Japan and negative interest rates, thus the 0% return.
Using 15% volatility and a modest 2.5% expected return (little confidence on the expected return).

Current futures at 19,590. As with the U.S. so goes the rest of the world. Demographic head winds will continue to slow consumer consumption. That said I'm lowering 1st category to 5% from 30%, raised 2nd to 45% from 30%, 3rd to 30%, 4th and 5th remain the same. Japan continues to rely on U.S. consumers. Unless consumers have more disposable income there will remain lower consumption. Younger people are the ones who consume and most have stifling debt. Republican policies, (health insurance and taxes) favor the rich and especially health insurance policy could hurt middle and lower income people.
Decreasing the lowest slot 10% and increasing the 2 upper slots 5%. Less downside as still there is still a lot of liquidity available and fixed income returns favor risk.
with the military tensions in the region, I adjusted down  the 20k - 22k to 5% from 10%.
My prediction is a gut feeling we're due for a worldwide recession.
Reduce certainty at tails, increase center.

Admitting I didn't know anything about the Nikkei until this question, the index seems to have a slow upward trajectory; notwithstanding many downturns. With that in mind, Japan's economic policy has been expansionist for years and that looks set to continue through 2017. I think the monetary and fiscal stimulus of the economy will keep the market strong.
Keep an eye on what the Bank of Japan does.

looking at a 30 year monthly chart of $NIKK you see that it has been in this broad trading range from 21k to 7k area.  Monthly and weekly stochastics look bearish. "JOTARO SAITO Tokyo Fashion Week Fall 2016 by Fashion Channel"
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zI8K_hwJ1O4 comment:  Besides the charts I took a social mood indicator of fashion.  The Kimonos worn are dark in color, low sheen, and mat.  The back ground is dark, the carpet is dark.  This is just another indicator of the negative social mood of the people.  I suspect a retest of the multi-year trading range lows.
Toyota, Mitsubishi, Hitachi, Sony, Marubeni, Fuji, Mazds, Nippon will grow in 2017. Moderate growth is more welcome in Japan companies. More inflation, more money, more prices, more index.
Nikkei is at the high end currently, but still staying low.19,469.17

The overall outlook for Japan remains positive with 0.5-1.5 % GDP growth forecast for 2017 and inflation approaching 1 %. The current account is expected to remain fairly stable at 3.5 % of GDP http://www.economist.com/news/economic-and-financial-indicators/21714361-economist-poll-forecasters-january-averages The border adjustment tax planned by the Trump administration may hurt exports, especially in the tech sector which almost half of the index is comprised of. On the other hand, a strengthening USD vis-a-vis the JPY will counter that headwind. Also demand is increasing in Europe and in Emerging Markets holding steady. The BOJ will likely start to taper its bond purchases, with a switch from aggressive accommodation to more of a fine tuning of the yield curve https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-03-03/boj-replaces-key-policy-planner-amid-new-focus-on-yield-control. The reduction in central bank liquidity coupled with a possible rate hike might depress equities slightly. All in all would expect the Nikkei to end up close to its current levels, with a few contrarian forces carrying roughly equal weight. The longer term problem of an ageing population could increase the downsize risk.

-wakening of the jpy compared to usd as a result of ir hikes and upward re-adjustment of japaneese company earnings
-attractive long term valuations
-companies with large overseas exposures which predicted a stronger usd have already set aside capital for increased costs; the ones exporting will see a major uptick in profitability
-low unemployment rates and continued increase in wages
-Abe's swift reaction to meet with Trump to discuss the relationship of Japan with the new administration
Weaker yen, recovering macro, a few positive corporate governance stories, valuations attractive if cash on balance sheet has value

NIKKEI has a strong correlation with the Yen. Given BoJ's very accomodotative stance, the JPY will likely weaken further, supporting the NIKKEI. Also growth data in Japan point to decent domestic growth. But a risk-off envinronment may lead to a much stronger Yen which can easily cause a large drop in the Nikkei. US protectionist policies are also a risk
The yen is likely to weaken slightly. That will hamper the market's ability to make a dramatic rise.
Nikkei at a 52 week high today, hard to imagine the two extremes coming into play.
N has not been growing much lately, and a trade war is not unlikely
JPY has sold off into year end in each of the last five years and the BoJ QE program is not scheduled to end in the foreseeable future, but that is a risk.
Abe is using every monetary tool he can think of to boost the Japanese economy
Tails are too small.  Increasing same.  Nikkei is 19283 today.
